s.gd: Dh’fhaodadh an aimlisg a tha anns an eachdraidh seo tachairt do dhuine sam bith.
s.en: The confusion that is in this story could happen to anyone at all.

s.gd: Cha b’ e nach robh mi faiceallach bu choireach gun thachair e idir, ach nach robh mi amharasach gu leòr.
s.en: It was not that I was not careful that was to blame that it happened at all, but but that I was not suspicious enough.

s.gd: Nan robh mi air aon cheum eile a dhèanamh a bharrachd air na rinn mi - ach mus cuir sibh cus coire orm, beachdaichibh an robh sibh air an ceum sin a dhèanamh.
s.en: If I had taken one other step in addition to what I did – but before you blame me too much, think whether you would have taken that step.

s.gd: Tha an taigh againne agus taigh Eilidh, nighean mo pheathar, ri taobh a chèile.
s.en: Our house and Helen’s house, my sister’s girl, are next to each other.

s.gd: Tha Murchadh, an duine aig Eilidh, na mhanaidsear air companaidh a tha a’ dèanamh choimpiutairean agus tha iad gu math nas beartaiche na a’ mhòr-chuid a tha sa choimhearsnachd.
s.en: Murdo, Helen’s husband, is a manager at a company that makes computers and they are much wealthier than the majority who are in the community.

s.gd: Tha taigh mòr aca agus tha e làn dhe gach uidheam as fheàrr.
s.en: Thy have a big house and it is full of all the best appliances.

s.gd: A h-uile samhradh tha iad a’ dol air làithean-saora, agus am bliadhna ’s ann dhan Spàinn a chaidh iad.
s.en: Every summer they went on holiday, and this year they went to Spain.

s.gd: Mar as àbhaist, dh’fhàg iad iuchar an taighe agamsa, agus mar as àbhaist bha mi a’ coimhead às dèidh an àite a cheart cho cùramach ’s a sheallainn às dèidh mo dhachaigh fhìn.
s.en: As usual, they left the house key with me, and as usual I was looking after the place just as carefully as I would look after my own home.

s.gd: Seachdain an dèidh dhaibh falbh thàinig bhan mhòr chun an taighe againn, agus ainm bùth àirneis ainmeil air a cliathaich.
s.en: A week after thet left a large van came to out house, with the name of a famouse furniture store on its side.

s.gd: Thàinig gille mòr, tapaidh, modhail chun an dorais.
s.en: A big, strong, polite man came to the door.

s.gd: “Tha mi duilich dragh a chur oirbh,” ars esan.
s.en: “I am sorry to disturb you,” he said.

s.gd: “Tha mi a’ coimhead gu bheil mi aig an taigh cheàrr.
s.en: “I see that I am at the wrong house.

s.gd: ’S e àireamh dhà air fhichead a tha mi a’ lorg.”
s.en: It’s number twelve I am looking for.”

s.gd: “An ath dhoras,” arsa mise, “ach tha iad air falbh an-dràsta air làithean-saora.”
s.en: “The next door,” I said, “but they are away just now on holidays.”

s.gd: “Cha do dh’innis iad dhuinn gu robh iad a’ falbh,” ars esan.
s.en: “They didn’t tell us that they were leaving,” he said.

s.gd: “Tha preas aodaich agam sa bhan ...”
s.en: “I have a wardrobe in the van ...”

s.gd: “Tha an iuchar agam fhìn,” arsa mise, “agus fosglaidh mi an doras dhut.”
s.en: “I have the key myself,” I said, “and I will open the door for you.”

s.gd: Chaidh mi còmhla ris a’ ghille agus cha robh e fhèin agus fear a bha ga chuideachadh fada a’ cur a-steach preas aodaich mòr brèagha.
s.en: I went along with the lad and he himself and a man who was helping him were not long in putting a big beautiful wardrobe inside.

s.gd: Cha robh fios agam càit an robh Eilidh ag iarraidh a chur, agus thuirt mi ri na balaich fhàgail anns an talla, agus a thighinn a-steach dhan chidsin airson cofaidh.
s.en: I didn’t know where Helen wanted it put, and I said to the lads to leave it in the hall, and to come into the kitchen for a coffee.

s.gd: Ghlas mi an doras às mo dhèidh agus cha tug mi smaoin tuilleadh air a’ ghnothaich.
s.en: I locked the door behind me and I didn’t give any more thought to the matter.

s.gd: Mu dhà uair a thìde an dèidh sin thàinig an gille air ais, làn leisgeulan airson dragh a chur orm a-rithist.
s.en: Around two hours after that the lad came back, full of apologies from disturbing me again.

s.gd: “’S ann dhan taigh cheàrr a chuir sinn am preas aodaich,” ars esan.
s.en: “We put the wardrobe into the wrong house,” he said.

s.gd: “Thug iad dhomh an seòladh ceàrr anns a’ bhùth.
s.en: “They gave me the wrong address in the shop.

s.gd: Tha an àireamh ceart ach ’s e an t-sràid cheàrr a th’ ann.
s.en: The number is correct but it is the wrong street.

s.gd: An dùil am b’ urrainn dhuibh ...?”
s.en: Wondering if you could ...?”

s.gd: “Cùm thusa ort mionaid,” arsa mise, agus chaidh mi a dh’iarraidh iuchar taigh Eilidh.
s.en: “Hold on a minute,” I said, and I went to fetch Helen’s house key.

s.gd: Cha robh na balaich fada a’ falbh leis an àirneis agus ghlas mi an doras ’s chaidh mi dhachaigh.
s.en: The lads were not long in leaving with the furniture and I locked the door and I went home.

s.gd: Cha robh guth agam air a’ chùis gus an d’ fhuair mi fios gu robh Eilidh is Murchadh a’ tighinn, agus chaidh mi chun a’ phuirt-adhair nan coinneimh.
Ach mo chreach-sa thàinig: nuair a chaidh sinn a-steach dhan taigh chunna mi an t-uamhann ann an aghaidh Eilidh.
Bha a h-uile càil luachmhor a bha am broinn an taighe air a ghoid: dà thelebhisean, bhidio, dà rèidio, reacòrdair, seudan, camanan goilf agus fiù an cleoc mòr a bha anns an talla.
Chaidh sinn timcheall an taighe a shealltainn an robh doras no uinneag fosgailte, ach cha robh.
“Robh sibh còmhla ri na daoine fad na tìde?” ars Eilidh.
“Cha do leig mi aon mhionaid às mo shealladh iad,” arsa mise.
Cha b’ fhada gus an tàinig dà lorg-phoileas agus abair gun rinn iad sgrùdadh ormsa.”
Bha amharas aca gu robh gnothaich air choreigin agam ris an eucoir.
Ach nuair a chuala iad mo sgeulachd, mhothaich mi gun tug iad sùil air a chèile.
Thuirt an dara fear rium: “Cha leig thu leas a bhith gad àrach fhèin.
Tha an dearbh rud air tachairt sa bhaile dà thuras an t-seachdain seo.
“Dè mar a fhuair iad a-steach?” dh’fhaighnich Murchadh.
“Chan eil comharradh sam bith gun bhris iad a-steach.”
“Cha do bhris iad a-steach idir,” ars am poileasman.
“Tha iad nas teòma na sin.
Tha sinne cinnteach dè mar a tha iad ga dhèanamh.
Nuair a thig iad leis an àirneis, bidh duine beag aca na bhroinn.
Mus till iad ga iarraidh bidh esan air am preas aodaich a lìonadh, agus bidh e fhèin còmhla ris an stuth nuair a dh’fhalbhas an dithis eile leis a’ phreas aodaich.”
Nuair a bha iad a’ falbh, dh’fhaighnich fear aca dhomh na mhothaich mi an robh miotagan air na daoine, agus thuirt mi gu robh.
“Cha tug iad dhiubh idir iad?” ars esan.
Chuimhnich mi an uair sin air a’ chofaidh a thug mi dhaibh, agus gun teagamh thug iad dhiubh na miotagan fhad ’s a bha iad ga òl.
Bha na mugaichean sa chidsin far na dh’fhàg mi iad gun an nighe, oir cha robh mi airson na daoine a leigeil às mo shealladh.
’S ann mar sin a chaidh na h-eucoraich a dhìteadh.
Bha làraich am meuran air an dà mhuga.
Ach beachdaichibh a-nise: an robh sibhse air am preas aodaich ud fhosgladh?
s.en: But think now: would you have opened that wardrobe?
